head.abstracts: © 2016 Yuka KANEKO, Katsumi MATSUOKA and Toshihisa TOYODA.This chapter looks at Canterbury’s progress as the province enters its fourth year of recovery. It also looks briefly at the impetus of the overarching first insurer, the Earthquake Commission (EQC), and provides a snapshot of Canterbury’s general recovery amid residents’ continuing frustrations over rebuilding and building repair. The chapter makes only brief mention of this extremely contentious aspect of Canterbury’s earthquake recovery. It concentrates on the class where properties had no insurance either vacant land or uninsured residential properties. The chapter also addresses the three Court decisions, all of which provide a rare glimpse of the intersection of public law and real property law as it is assessed under the overriding umbrella of New Zealand’s emergency legislation, the CER Act 2011. On 28 March 2011 the Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority (CERA) was established. The Bill that became the Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Act 2011 was introduced to Parliament and passed through all parliamentary stages on 12 April 2011.
